A.4 Proof of Corollary 3.6

Assume all elements of 𝒜~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} come from the same client k𝑘k. Let’s consider x∈𝒜th𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒜ℎ𝑡x\in\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}. According to Theorem 3.5, there exists x′∈𝒜~t,0hsuperscript𝑥′subscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡0x^{\prime}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} such that x𝑥x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} are from the same client. As x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} comes from client k𝑘k, x𝑥x comes from client k𝑘k. Therefore, all elements x∈𝒜th𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒜ℎ𝑡x\in\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t} come from client k𝑘k. In particular, if 𝒜~t,0hsubscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t,0} contains only one element, by 2.4, this element belongs to one and only one client k𝑘k. The result then follows.

Appendix B Recovering the activation sets using Orthogonal matching pursuit

The goal of this section is to explain how we do the second step of SRATTA described in Step 2 of Section 3.2.

B.1 Problem reformulation

Recall from Equation 8 that for each couple (t,h)𝑡ℎ(t,h) of neurons and rounds, we try to find N∈ℕ𝑁ℕN\in\mathbb{N}, (λr)1≤r≤Nsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑟1𝑟𝑁(\lambda_{r})_{1\leq r\leq N} and (xr)1≤r≤N∈ℛNsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑟1𝑟𝑁superscriptℛ𝑁(x_{r})_{1\leq r\leq N}\in\mathcal{R}^{N} such that

Δ​WthΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑊ℎ𝑡\displaystyle\Delta W^{h}_{t} =∑r=1Nλr​xrabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑁subscript𝜆𝑟subscript𝑥𝑟\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r}x_{r} (19a)
Δ​bthΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑏ℎ𝑡\displaystyle\Delta b^{h}_{t} =∑r=1Nλrabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑁subscript𝜆𝑟\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}\lambda_{r} (19b)
∀r,for-all𝑟\displaystyle\forall r,\ λr≠0subscript𝜆𝑟0\displaystyle\lambda_{r}\neq 0 (19c)

Let us reformulate Equation 19. Denote with Nℛsubscript𝑁ℛN_{\mathcal{R}} the number of recovered samples in ℛℛ\mathcal{R} and let x1,..,xNℛ∈ℛx_{1},..,x_{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\in\mathcal{R} be the list of recovered samples. Let X​=def​(x1,…,xNℛ)⊤∈ℝNℛ×d𝑋defsuperscriptsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥subscript𝑁ℛtopsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑁ℛ𝑑X\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}(x_{1},...,x_{N_{\mathcal{R}}})^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}\times d} be the matrix of recovered samples, and X¯​=def​(X𝟏)∈ℝNℛ×(d+1)¯𝑋defmatrix𝑋1superscriptℝsubscript𝑁ℛ𝑑1\overline{X}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\begin{pmatrix}X&\mathbf{1}\end{pmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}\times(d+1)} be the extended recovered samples matrix. Equation 19 can simply be written

 Find ​λ∈ℝNℛ​ s.t. ​X¯⊤​λ=W¯th, Find 𝜆superscriptℝsubscript𝑁ℛ s.t. superscript¯𝑋top𝜆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡\text{ Find }\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\text{ s.t. }\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda=\overline{W}^{h}_{t}, (20)

and a recovered activation set can be defined from λ𝜆\lambda as the set of recovered samples whose corresponding coefficient λrsubscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{r} is non zero, that is 𝒜~th​(λ)​=def​{xr∈ℛ:λr≠0}subscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡𝜆defconditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑟ℛsubscript𝜆𝑟0\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda)\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\{x_{r}\in\mathcal{R}\leavevmode\nobreak\ :\leavevmode\nobreak\ \lambda_{r}\neq 0\}.

B.2 Restriction to small activation sets

Solving Equation 20 and using a resulting λ𝜆\lambda to build the recovered activation set 𝒜~th​(λ)subscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡𝜆\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda) is not satisfactory. Indeed, as soon as Nℛ>d+1subscript𝑁ℛ𝑑1N_{\mathcal{R}}>d+1 there are infinitely many solutions to Equation 20, corresponding to potentially infinitely many recovered activation set 𝒜~th​(λ)subscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡𝜆\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda). In that case, there is no way of knowing which one of these approximations is actually the true activation set.

As explained in the main text (see Section 3.2), to avoid this problem, we further constrain Equation 20 to the λ𝜆\lambda corresponding to activation sets of size at most Nmaxsubscript𝑁maxN_{\textrm{max}}, where Nmaxsubscript𝑁maxN_{\textrm{max}} is a hyper-parameter selected by the attacker in order to recover meaningful activation sets, and where Nmax≪dmuch-less-thansubscript𝑁max𝑑N_{\textrm{max}}\ll d in order to avoid the problem of having infinitely many solutions. This can be formalized as the following problem

 Find ​λ∈ℝNℛ​ such that ​‖λ‖0≤Nmax​ and ​X¯⊤​λ=W¯th, Find 𝜆superscriptℝsubscript𝑁ℛ such that subscriptnorm𝜆0subscript𝑁max and superscript¯𝑋top𝜆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡\text{ Find }\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\text{ such that }\|\lambda\|_{0}\leq N_{\textrm{max}}\text{ and }\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda=\overline{W}^{h}_{t}, (21)

where ‖λ‖0subscriptnorm𝜆0\|\lambda\|_{0} denotes the number of non zero coefficients of λ𝜆\lambda. The intuition behind this restriction is that (i) we wish to recover small activation sets and (ii) it is much less likely that Equation 21 has a solution with a small Nmaxsubscript𝑁maxN_{\textrm{max}}, so that if we find one, the corresponding 𝒜~th​(λ)subscriptsuperscript~𝒜ℎ𝑡𝜆\widetilde{\mathcal{A}}^{h}_{t}(\lambda) is likely to be equal to the true activation set 𝒜thsubscriptsuperscript𝒜ℎ𝑡\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t}. In practice, to solve Equation 21, we solve the relaxed version

 Find ​λ∈ℝNℛ​ such that ​λ∈arg⁡min‖λ‖0≤Nmax⁡‖X¯⊤​λ−W¯th‖2. Find 𝜆superscriptℝsubscript𝑁ℛ such that 𝜆subscriptsubscriptnorm𝜆0subscript𝑁maxsuperscriptnormsuperscript¯𝑋top𝜆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡2\text{ Find }\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N_{\mathcal{R}}}\text{ such that }\lambda\in\arg\min_{\|\lambda\|_{0}\leq N_{\textrm{max}}}\left\|\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda-\overline{W}^{h}_{t}\right\|^{2}. (22)

We then check that the recovered solution λ𝜆\lambda satisfies X¯⊤​λ=W¯thsuperscript¯𝑋top𝜆subscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡\overline{X}^{\top}\lambda=\overline{W}^{h}_{t} with sufficient precision (if it is not the case, this means that Equation 21 has no solution). In the main paper, we denote with Lrecsubscript𝐿recL_{\textrm{rec}} the set of couples (t,h)𝑡ℎ(t,h) for which Equation 21 has a solution.

This last formulation is quite standard, and can be solved using different methods, such as orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP), Rubinstein et al. [2008], Mallat and Zhang [1993] or the LASSO method Kim et al. [2007]. In practice, we solve this problem using OMP, and Nmaxsubscript𝑁maxN_{\textrm{max}} is selected in order to lead to clusters of reasonable size. OMP is based on a greedy algorithm and builds the activation set iteratively. At each step, it adds to the activation set the sample which is most highly correlated with the residual. It is called orthogonal matching pursuit because at each iteration, the residual is recomputed using an orthogonal projection on the current state of the activation set. For more details, see Mallat and Zhang [1993] as well as the scikit-learn documentation Pedregosa et al. [2011].

Appendix C Relaxation of hypotheses

We note that although we assume full-participation in the rest of the article it is not strictly necessary for SRATTA to work. In addition, the local and global learning rate, batch size, number of updates do not have to be fixed. The only important thing is to perform multiple gradient updates, and that the learning rate is the same for the weights and the bias at each local minibatch’s gradient step. The sum across clients could be weighted (in fact this can be included in the label variable, by adding an extra label variable k𝑘k for the client).

Appendix D Pseudocode of SRATTA

The pseudocode of SRATTA can be found below in Algorithm 3.

Appendix E Details on numerical experiment

E.1 Details on numerical experiment

Additional details on the metrics used.

We can see the output of SRATTA as a partition of the set of recovered samples P1∪…∪Pp=ℛsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑝ℛP_{1}\cup...\cup P_{p}=\mathcal{R}, where the sets P1,…,Ppsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑝P_{1},...,P_{p} which are disjoint. The sets Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} are inferred by the attacker in step 3b), and represent the largest possible groups of samples which they can build. We will assess the quality of the sample recovery process using the following different metrics.

ρrecovered​=def​#​ℛ/#​𝒟subscript𝜌recovereddef#ℛ#𝒟\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\#\mathcal{R}/\#\mathcal{D} is the ratio of recovered samples and measures the quality of the recovery process.

ρmatchedsubscript𝜌matched\rho_{\mathrm{matched}} is the ratio of samples in the dataset which have been recovered and grouped with at least another sample (that is samples that belong to Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} with #​Pi>1#subscript𝑃𝑖1\#P_{i}>1).

ρcomponentsubscript𝜌component\rho_{\mathrm{component}} is the ratio between the average size of the K𝐾K biggest elements in the partition (P1,…,Pp)subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑝(P_{1},...,P_{p}) and the average size of a client dataset #​𝒟k#subscript𝒟𝑘\#\mathcal{D}_{k} (In practice, all client datasets will be of equal size). The intuition is that the K𝐾K biggest elements of the partition would ideally each correspond to a different client dataset.

Vnormalized​=def​ρrecovered∗Vrecoveredsubscript𝑉normalizeddefsubscript𝜌recoveredsubscript𝑉recoveredV_{\mathrm{normalized}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}}*V_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the normalized V𝑉V-measure of the grouped recovered samples, where Vrecoveredsubscript𝑉recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the V𝑉V-measure Rosenberg and Hirschberg [2007] of the partition (P1,…,Pp)subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑝(P_{1},...,P_{p}) of ℛℛ\mathcal{R} with respect to the true partition of ℛℛ\mathcal{R} into K𝐾K sets across the K𝐾K-clients. Exactly in the same way that the F​1𝐹1F1 score mixes precision and recall, here, the V𝑉V-measure mixes two measures of the quality of the partition P1,…,Ppsubscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑝P_{1},...,P_{p}: homogeneity h∈[0,1]ℎ01h\in[0,1] and completeness c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1]. Homogeneity measures the diversity of each class: h=1ℎ1h=1 if each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} contains elements coming from only one client (this will be the case if we have no false positive). Completeness measures how each true client is distributed amongst different groups Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} ; c=1𝑐1c=1 if for all k𝑘k, all elements belonging to client k𝑘k are assigned to the same element of the partition Piksubscript𝑃subscript𝑖𝑘P_{i_{k}}. Vrecoveredsubscript𝑉recoveredV_{\mathrm{recovered}} is the harmonic mean of these two quantities, so that Vrecovered=0subscript𝑉recovered0V_{\mathrm{recovered}}=0 if either c,h=0𝑐ℎ0c,h=0 and Vrecovered=1subscript𝑉recovered1V_{\mathrm{recovered}}=1 if both c,h=1𝑐ℎ1c,h=1. This measure is particularly adapted to our setting as we do not have a natural metric to compare different clusterings with a different number of clusters. We multiply by ρrecoveredsubscript𝜌recovered\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}} so that the attacker clusters all data points and to the right client if and only if Vnormalized=1subscript𝑉normalized1V_{\mathrm{normalized}}=1. ρrecoveredsubscript𝜌recovered\rho_{\mathrm{recovered}} can be seen as the recall but taken over all samples not only recovered samples.

E.2 Datasets used

E.2.1 CIFAR10

CIFAR10 Krizhevsky et al. [2009] is one of the most well-known image classification datasets. There are 60,0006000060,000 object-centric images of relatively low resolution 32x32x3 that are labeled with 10 different mutually exclusive classes (horse, frog, truck, airplane, automobile, bird, cat, deer, dog, ship).

E.2.2 FashionMNIST

FashionMNIST Xiao et al. [2017] was released as a more challenging alternative to MNIST LeCun et al. [1998] with grayscale images 28x28 of fashion items split across 10 classes (T-shirt/top, Trouser, Pullover, Dress, Coat, Sandal, Shirt, Sneaker, Bag, Ankle boot). There are 70,0007000070,000 images in total.

E.2.3 DNA

Primate Splice-Junction Gene Sequences (or DNA dataset) dataset is a part of the OpenML suite Vanschoren et al. [2014]. It consists of 3,18631863,186 samples which are splice junctions. Each sample is a vector of 180180180 indicator binary variables and the ML task is a 3-way classification task (ei, ie, neither). More details can be found in Vanschoren et al. [2014].

For all the datasets above, we use MLP networks directly on raw pixels that are just rescaled to be between 0 and 1 (with 255 distinct values).

E.2.4 TCGA-BRCA

The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) Weinstein et al. [2013], Tomczak et al. [2015] is an open initiative to gather and make available oncology patients’ data for multiple modalities such as tabular, radiology, histology and genomics and different cancers. The TCGA is organized by study where each study focuses on a single cancer. BRCA is the BReast CAncer study. The samples in TCGA were collected across multiple institutions that are tagged by barcodes and identifiable, this is also the case for BRCA. FLamby Ogier du Terrail et al. [2022] uses such naturally split data inside TCGA-BRCA to provide a realistic distributed dataset where the ML task is survival prediction Jenkins [2005]. For a more complete treatment of the ML task defined by this dataset see Appendix F in Ogier du Terrail et al. [2022]. We use this tabular dataset with 108810881088 patients and retrieve for each patient a feature obtained from its histology slides (see Primer on histology below if needed). We detail below in Histology Preprocessing the exact process used to extract such features and join both datasets.

TCGA license

The data terms can be found https://gdc.cancer.gov/access-data/data-access-processes-and-tools. In particular, as per the GDC data access policy, users should not attempt to identify individual human research participants from whom the data were obtained.

Primer on histology

Histology slides Ghaznavi et al. [2013] are large-size images obtained by digitizing stained slices of biopsies of the patient’s tumor sites. Such images, called Whole Slide Images (WSI), generally comprises millions of pixels representing the slice at different resolution and comprise a large uninformative background. This background has to be removed to maximize the Peak-Signal-to-Noise-Ratio of the information inside the WSI. As this data usually does not fit in GPU RAM, its dimensions are reduced using tiling and feature extraction Courtiol et al. [2018].

Histology Preprocessing

Like in Andreux et al. [2020], we use natural splits and retrieve the original histology sides corresponding to each patient using the patient ID. As some patients have multiple histology slides we keep only the first one after alphabetical sorting. We drop all patients for which histology slides could not be found (383838 in total making a final total of 105010501050 patients). We then tile the matter on each slide at x20 magnification using a U-net Ronneberger et al. [2015] trained on an in-house dataset and compute ResNet-50 features He et al. [2016] pretrained on IMAGENET Deng et al. [2009] for each extracted tile. Therefore each patient is associated with a row of clinical data and a variable number of ResNet-50 features proportional to the amount of matter found on the corresponding slide. We then train a linear autoencoder with bottleneck size 256256256 on the ResNet-50 features from all slides using an L2 cost as is common practice Schmauch et al. [2020]. Once this autoencoder is trained, we encode all features in each slide. Finally, we average all autoencoded features on each slide to get a fixed-sized feature, following MeanPool architectures Saillard et al. [2021]. Therefore for each patient we build a feature vector of size 39+256=2953925629539+256=295 with 393939 clinical features and 256256256 "histology" features.

Clinical Data Preprocessing We use FLambyOgier du Terrail et al. [2022]’s preprocessed version of TCGA-BRCA where original features are filtered and binarized except for the age feature (of integer type), which is left unaltered. This allows us to easily define the corresponding data prior to filter out candidates. See Ogier du Terrail et al. [2022]’s Appendix F1 and Andreux et al. [2020] for more details about the exact preprocessing steps.

Survival Loss function

One of the foundation models in survival analysis is the linear Cox proportional hazard Cox [1972]. This model assumes:

h​(t,x)=h0​(t)​exp⁡(βT​x)ℎ𝑡𝑥subscriptℎ0𝑡superscript𝛽𝑇𝑥h(t,x)=h_{0}(t)\exp(\beta^{T}x) (23)

where h0subscriptℎ0h_{0} is the baseline hazard function (common to all patients and dependent on time only) and β𝛽\beta is the vector of parameters of our linear model. β𝛽\beta is estimated by minimization of the negative Cox partial log-likelihood, which compares relative risk ratios:

L​(β)=−∑i:δi=1[βT​xi−log⁡(∑j:tj>tiexp⁡(βT​xj))]𝐿𝛽subscript:𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖1delimited-[]superscript𝛽𝑇subscript𝑥𝑖subscript:𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑖superscript𝛽𝑇subscript𝑥𝑗L(\beta)=-\sum_{i:\delta_{i}=1}\Big{[}\beta^{T}x_{i}-\log\big{(}\sum_{j:t_{j}>t_{i}}\exp(\beta^{T}x_{j})\big{)}\Big{]} (24)

where i𝑖i and j𝑗j index patients and δi=1subscript𝛿𝑖1\delta_{i}=1 indicates an event. This loss is extended in our case to handling mθ​(xi)=ReLU​(W​xi+b)subscript𝑚𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖ReLU𝑊subscript𝑥𝑖𝑏m_{\theta}(x_{i})=\mathrm{ReLU}(Wx_{i}+b) instead of raw xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} where we backpropagate through W𝑊W and b𝑏b as well. This is a natural extension explored in Andreux et al. [2020]:

L​(β)=−∑i:δi=1[βT​mθ​(xi)−log⁡(∑j:tj>tiexp⁡(βT​mθ​(xj)))]𝐿𝛽subscript:𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖1delimited-[]superscript𝛽𝑇subscript𝑚𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖subscript:𝑗subscript𝑡𝑗subscript𝑡𝑖superscript𝛽𝑇subscript𝑚𝜃subscript𝑥𝑗L(\beta)=-\sum_{i:\delta_{i}=1}\Big{[}\beta^{T}m_{\theta}(x_{i})-\log\big{(}\sum_{j:t_{j}>t_{i}}\exp(\beta^{T}m_{\theta}(x_{j}))\big{)}\Big{]} (25)

We minimize the negative Cox partial log-likelihood by mini-batch gradient descent w.r.t. β𝛽\beta. We note that, as this loss is non-separable, its gradient on mini-batches might be degenerate if the sampled batch contains only non-admissible pairs that cannot be ranked together Jenkins [2005].

All experiments in the article on the presented datasets are repeated 101010 times in order to produce confidence intervals.

E.3 Dirichlet split of the dataset across the clients.

In Section 4.2 and Figure 2, we use the same method as Hsu et al. [2019] to split the FashionMNIST dataset into different clients, while parameterizing the heterogeneity of the data distribution by a parameter 0<α<∞0𝛼0<\alpha<\infty. A small value of α𝛼\alpha corresponds to a heterogeneous data distribution, while a high value of α𝛼\alpha corresponds to a homogeneous data distribution.

More precisely, for a given value of α𝛼\alpha and a given client k𝑘k, we draw a random vector q→→𝑞\vec{q} following a Dirichlet distribution of parameter α𝛼\alpha of size L=10𝐿10L=10, where L𝐿L is the number of labels present in FashionMNIST. Such a vector satisfies ‖q→‖1=1subscriptnorm→𝑞11\|\vec{q}\|_{1}=1 and ql≥0subscript𝑞𝑙0q_{l}\geq 0 for l=1,…,L𝑙1…𝐿l=1,\dots,L. The density distribution of q→→𝑞\vec{q} is proportional to ∏lqlαsubscriptproduct𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑙𝛼\prod_{l}q_{l}^{\alpha}. For the client k𝑘k, we then generate a dataset of size #​𝒟k#subscript𝒟𝑘\#\mathcal{D}_{k}, such that the number of samples with label l𝑙l is roughly ⌊ql​#​𝒟k⌋subscript𝑞𝑙#subscript𝒟𝑘\lfloor q_{l}\#\mathcal{D}_{k}\rfloor.

When α→∞→𝛼\alpha\to\infty, we have ql→1/L→subscript𝑞𝑙1𝐿q_{l}\to 1/L for all l𝑙l, therefore each client k𝑘k as #​𝒟k/L#subscript𝒟𝑘𝐿\#\mathcal{D}_{k}/L samples of each label. When α→0→𝛼0\alpha\to 0, we have q→→(0.,…,0,1,0,…)\vec{q}\to(0.,\dots,0,1,0,\dots), where the only non-zero component of q→→𝑞\vec{q} is randomly one of the L𝐿L dimensions. In that case, each client has samples coming from only one label.

We provide in Figure 3 an extension of Figure 2 where we added the performance of two extra clustering algorithms: the BIRCH Zhang et al. [1996] and the Affinity propagation Frey and Dueck [2007]. We could not empirically make the attack works with other standard clustering algorithms.

E.4 Effect of different hyperparameters on the strength of SRATTA

In this section, we give more details as to the effect of different hyper parameters on the strength of SRATTA. Figures 4 and 5 shows the impact of the batch size, the number of hidden neurons, the learning rate, the number of rounds, the number of trainings and the number of updates per round in the efficiency of SRATTA.

Appendix F Defending against secure disaggregation

This section is devoted to the defense presented in Section 5, that we will name q𝑞q-defense. We first state definitions used in the main text then we provide details and extra-results on the q𝑞q-defense in Section F.1. Then, in Section F.3, we develop and implement another kind of defense, denoted β𝛽\beta-defense, which is similar to the one presented in Section F.1, but relies on another way of selecting the neurons to censor.

F.1 Additional definitions for the q𝑞q-defense

In Section 5, given a client k𝑘k, we define the individual client activation set of neuron hℎh at round t𝑡t as

𝒜t,kh=⋃i=0nupdates−1𝒜h​(θt,k,i,Bt,k,i).subscriptsuperscript𝒜ℎ𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑛updates1superscript𝒜ℎsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝐵𝑡𝑘𝑖\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t,k}=\bigcup_{i=0}^{n_{\mathrm{updates}}-1}{\mathcal{A}^{h}(\theta_{t,k,i},B_{t,k,i})}. (26)

One can write the update of a specific client k𝑘k as

Δ​W¯t,kh​=def​W¯t,k,nupdatesh−W¯t−1h.Δsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡𝑘defsubscriptsuperscript¯𝑊ℎ𝑡𝑘subscript𝑛updatessuperscriptsubscript¯𝑊𝑡1ℎ\Delta\overline{W}^{h}_{t,k}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\overline{W}^{h}_{t,k,n_{\mathrm{updates}}}-\overline{W}_{t-1}^{h}. (27)

Exactly as is the case for the round-level activation set, the update of a specific client is a linear combination of the elements in its activation set.

Fix a client k𝑘k, a neuron hℎh, and t∈{1,…,tmax}𝑡1…subscript𝑡maxt\in\{1,...,t_{\mathrm{max}}\}. Let x1,…,xNsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑁x_{1},...,x_{N} denote the activation points in 𝒜t,khsubscriptsuperscript𝒜ℎ𝑡𝑘\mathcal{A}^{h}_{t,k}. There exists non zero coefficients (λr)∈ℝ∖{0}Nsubscript𝜆𝑟ℝsuperscript0𝑁(\lambda_{r})\in\mathbb{R}\setminus{\{0\}}^{N} such that

Δ​Wt,khΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑊ℎ𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\Delta W^{h}_{t,k} =∑r=1Nλr​xrabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑁subscript𝜆𝑟subscript𝑥𝑟\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}{\lambda_{r}x_{r}} (28)
Δ​bthΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑏ℎ𝑡\displaystyle\Delta b^{h}_{t} =∑r=1Nλrabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑁subscript𝜆𝑟\displaystyle=\sum_{r=1}^{N}{\lambda_{r}} (29)

The q𝑞q-defense, introduced in Section 5, consists in keeping track of the individual client activation set of all neurons, and censoring the update for neurons whose individual client activation set is non-empty and of size inferior to q𝑞q.

Considering a client k𝑘k, let fix q=1𝑞1q=1 and h~~ℎ\tilde{h} be such a neuron, i.e:

#​𝒜t,kh~=1.#subscriptsuperscript𝒜~ℎ𝑡𝑘1\#\mathcal{A}^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k}=1. (30)

For this neuron, there exists a data sample such that {x}=𝒜t,kh~𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒜~ℎ𝑡𝑘\{x\}=\mathcal{A}^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k}, which can be recovered by the first step of the attack, as from Equation 8:

Δ​Wt,kh~Δsubscriptsuperscript𝑊~ℎ𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\Delta W^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k} =λ​xabsent𝜆𝑥\displaystyle=\lambda x (31a)
Δ​bt,kh~Δsubscriptsuperscript𝑏~ℎ𝑡𝑘\displaystyle\Delta b^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k} =λabsent𝜆\displaystyle=\lambda (31b)
λ𝜆\displaystyle\lambda ≠0absent0\displaystyle\neq 0 (31c)

To avoid this situation, the defense relies on censoring this neuron, which means to set to zero the update sent to the server for h~~ℎ\tilde{h}. We define an integer threshold q𝑞q, and censor neurons whose individual client activation sets are smaller than q𝑞q. The resulting algorithm is depicted in Algorithm 4. This defense therefore requires an active role of the client.

LABEL:fig:defense_acc_and_prun_all_datasets and Table 2 shows the efficiency of the q𝑞q-defense against the attack. Note that if some samples are still recovered with q=1𝑞1q=1, using q=4𝑞4q=4 leads to a perfect defense (no sample recovered) in our experiments.

F.2 Additional results for q𝑞q-defense

Table 2 shows the complete results of the q𝑞q-defense on the different datasets, and Figure 7(d) shows the proportion of censored neurons by q𝑞q-defense for different learning rates.

Both show the efficiency of the q𝑞q-defense against SRATTA. Note that if some samples are still recovered with q=1𝑞1q=1, using q=4𝑞4q=4 leads to perfect defense (no sample recovered) in our experiments. In practice, samples can be recovered if 𝒜t,kh~subscriptsuperscript𝒜~ℎ𝑡𝑘\mathcal{A}^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k} is not a singleton, in the case where one of the λrsubscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{r} in Equation 28 is an order of magnitude larger than the others in absolute value.

F.3 Another possible defense: the β𝛽\beta-defense

We introduce in this section another defense, named "β𝛽\beta-defense". Increasing the value of q𝑞q is an efficient way to avoid sample recovery. However, it might censor more neurons than needed. Indeed, as mentioned above, if #​𝒜t,kh~>1#subscriptsuperscript𝒜~ℎ𝑡𝑘1\#\mathcal{A}^{\tilde{h}}_{t,k}>1 for a given neuron h~~ℎ\tilde{h}, a sample xrsubscript𝑥𝑟x_{r} can be recovered if its associated λrsubscript𝜆𝑟\lambda_{r} in Equation 6 is larger than the other λjsubscript𝜆𝑗\lambda_{j} by an order of magnitude. Note that for each neuron hℎh, for each sample xrsubscript𝑥𝑟x_{r} involved in the local training, the corresponding λrhsubscriptsuperscript𝜆ℎ𝑟\lambda^{h}_{r} can be computed by the client. Following the computation of Section A.2, one can derive

Δ​Wt,kh=−η​∑i=0nupdates−1∑j=0bλ​(θt,k,i;xjBki,yjBki)​xjΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑊ℎ𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑛updates1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑏𝜆subscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘subscript𝑥𝑗\Delta W^{h}_{t,k}=-\eta\sum_{i=0}^{n_{\mathrm{updates}}-1}{\sum_{j=0}^{b}\lambda(\theta_{t,k,i};x_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}},y_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}})x_{j}}
Δ​bt,kh=−η​∑i=0nupdates−1∑j=0bλ​(θt,k,i;xjBki,yjBki)Δsubscriptsuperscript𝑏ℎ𝑡𝑘𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑛updates1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑏𝜆subscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘\Delta b^{h}_{t,k}=-\eta\sum_{i=0}^{n_{\mathrm{updates}}-1}{\sum_{j=0}^{b}\lambda(\theta_{t,k,i};x_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}},y_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}})}

with λ​(θ;x,y)=∂ℒ​(θ;x,y)∂zh​𝟏Wh​x+bh>0𝜆𝜃𝑥𝑦ℒ𝜃𝑥𝑦superscript𝑧ℎsubscript1superscript𝑊ℎ𝑥superscript𝑏ℎ0\lambda(\theta;x,y)=\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}(\theta;x,y)}{\partial z^{h}}\mathbf{1}_{W^{h}x+b^{h}>0}. These last quantities are tractable by the client during the local update. We introduce a threshold β𝛽\beta and we censor all neurons for which there exists x~∈⋃i=0nupdates−1𝒜h​(θt,k,i,Bt,k,i)~𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑛updates1superscript𝒜ℎsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝐵𝑡𝑘𝑖\tilde{x}\in\bigcup_{i=0}^{n_{\mathrm{updates}}-1}{\mathcal{A}^{h}(\theta_{t,k,i},B_{t,k,i})}, and its associated λ~~𝜆\tilde{\lambda} such that:

|λ~|∑i=0nupdates−1∑j=0b|λ​(θt,k,i;xjBki,yjBki)|≥β~𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑛updates1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑏𝜆subscript𝜃𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑘𝛽\frac{|\tilde{\lambda}|}{\sum_{i=0}^{n_{\mathrm{updates}}-1}{\sum_{j=0}^{b}|\lambda(\theta_{t,k,i};x_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}},y_{j}^{B^{i}_{k}})|}}\geq\beta (32)

In plain english, if the linear weight of a sample contributes to the update more than a fraction β𝛽\beta, we censor the neuron. We name this other defense β𝛽\beta-defense, different to the q𝑞q-defense in the way it selects the neurons to censor. The results exhibited in Figures 6, 7 and 3 highlights that we are able while censoring less neurons using the β𝛽\beta-defense than when using the q𝑞q-defense with q=4𝑞4q=4, we successfully defend ourselves against the attack. Note that in these results the q𝑞q-defense is never used, as the β𝛽\beta-defense comes as a replacement of the q𝑞q-defense.

F.4 Remark on preserving symmetry with nupdates=1subscript𝑛updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}=1.

The second part of the attack is relevant only if nupdates>1subscript𝑛updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}>1, which is the setting this paper focus on. It could be seen as a possible way of defending against SRATTA. However enforcing nupdates=1subscript𝑛updates1n_{\mathrm{updates}}=1 by either (i) considering one batch in each round or (ii) accumulating gradient at the initial point θt−1subscript𝜃𝑡1\theta_{t-1}, boils down to distributed SGD. This algorithm is not suitable in all FL settings as it comes with high communication costs McMahan et al. [2017], and is more sensitive to gradient attacks, as studied by other work Geiping et al. [2020], Huang et al. [2021], Hatamizadeh et al. , Xu et al. [2022]. As a result we do not explore this further.
